text:
Q: How to handle tasks that depend on the outcome of other tasks A:

I think the better option will be adding a Cron Job service in your case. You want a trigger message sender so Cron Job is for you <3.

Q: Sorting a list of objects by an attribute's substring A:

tl;dr

Parse your input text as a LocalDate, then sort by extracting the day-of-month.

LocalDate.parse( 
    "Thu Oct 26 2023" , 
    DateTimeFormatter
        .ofPattern( "EEE MMM d uuuu" )
        .withLocale( Locale.of( "en" , "US" ) ) 
)

events.sort( Comparator.comparingInt( event -> event.when.getDayOfMonth() ) );

LocalDate

Treat your data by the proper type rather than mere text.

Your input is a date value, year-month-day. So use the java.time.LocalDate class built into Java 8+.

DateTimeFormatter

Define a formatting pattern to match your input.

String input = "Thu Oct 26 2023" ;
Locale locale = Locale.of( "en" , "US" ) ;  // In earlier Java, Locale.forLanguageTag( "en-US" ). 
DateTimeFormatter formatter = 
    DateTimeFormatter
        .ofPattern( "EEE MMM d uuuu" )
        .withLocale( locale ) ; 
LocalDate date = LocalDate.parse( input , formatter ) ;

See this code run at Ideone.com.

You may choose to cache that DateTimeFormatter object as a static final.

Field of LocalDate

Define your class attribute as being of the type LocalDate.

If the main purpose of your class is to transparently communicate shallowly-immutable data, make it a record.

record Event ( String title , LocalDate when ) {}

Populate some sample data.

List < Event > events =
        new ArrayList <>(
                List.of(
                        new Event( "Meeting" , LocalDate.parse( "Thu Oct 26 2023" , formatter ) ) ,
                        new Event( "Lunch" , LocalDate.parse( "Mon Oct 23 2023" , formatter ) ) ,
                        new Event( "Gathering" , LocalDate.parse( "Tue Oct 24 2023" , formatter ) )
                )
        );

Dump to console.

events.forEach( IO :: println );

When run:

Event[title=Meeting, when=2023-10-26]
Event[title=Lunch, when=2023-10-23]
Event[title=Gathering, when=2023-10-24]

Sorting

Now sort that list. For demonstration, let's sort by date. We need a Comparator. A method references is a compact way of doing that.

Comparator by method reference

events.sort( Comparator.comparingInt( Event :: when ) );

Comparator by imperative code

But you want to sort by the day of the month alone. That is an odd request, but we can meet it.

events.sort( Comparator.comparingInt( event -> event.when.getDayOfMonth() ) );

When run, we see sorted results.

Event[title=Lunch, when=2023-10-23]
Event[title=Gathering, when=2023-10-24]
Event[title=Meeting, when=2023-10-26]

Q: Which one is best for 2026 Python developers , Python Data science or Python Django? A:

Best long-term growth (AI + analytics): Python Data Science

Best for product building & backend: Python Django

If your goal is flexibility:Learn Django first, then learn Data Science.

This is hopefully fixed by this commit: https://github.com/codenameone/CodenameOne/commit/72bf283bdaaefe5207bb9fd6787578e3ef61522c if not let me know with a fresh stack

Q: Tensorflow: Convert Tensor to numpy array then pass into a feed_dict A:

Theres a couple of things that you not are understanding really well. Throughout your graph you will work with Tensors. You define Tensors by either using tf.placeholder and feeding them in the session.run(feed_dict{}) or with tf.Variable and initializing it with session.run(tf.initialize_all_variables()). You must feed your input this way, and it should be numpy arrays in the same as shape as you expect in the placeholders. Here's a simple example:

images = tf.placeholder(type, [1728, BATCH_SIZE])
labels = tf.placeholder(type, [size])

'''
    Build your network here so you have the variable: Output
'''

images_feed, labels_feed = CIFARImageLoading.loadimagesandlabels(size=BATCH_SIZE)
# here you can see your output
print sess.run(Output, feed_dict = {x: images_feed, y_:labels_feed})

You do not feed tf.functions with numpy arrays, you always feed them with Tensors. And the feed_dict is always fed with numpy arrays. The thing is: you will never have to convert tensors to numpy arrays for the input, that does not make sense. Your input must be numpy arrays, if it's a list, you can use np.asarray(list), if it's a tensor, you are doing this wrong.

I do not know what CIFARImageLoading.loadimagesandlabels returns to you, but I imagine it's not a Tensor, it's probably a numpy array already, so just get rid of this .eval().
